DataElement.preferredName: Tumor Identifier Domain Neoplasm ICD-O-3 Behavior Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The code that identifies the behavior of a neoplasm as per ICD-O-3.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Tumor Identifier Domain Neoplasm ICD-O-3 Behavior Code
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A domain that represents the data that uniquely identifies tumors.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._The code for the behavior of the tumor being reported using ICD-O-3.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A domain that represents the data that uniquely identifies tumors.

Concepts.definition: A domain that represents the data that uniquely identifies tumors.

Property.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._The code for the behavior of the tumor being reported using ICD-O-3.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
The code for the behavior of the tumor being reported using ICD-O-3.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._The code for the behavior of the tumor being reported using ICD-O-3._A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neoplasm characterized by the absence of atypical or malignant cytological and architectural features, and absence of invasive features or metastatic potential.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm characterized by the absence of atypical or malignant cytological and architectural features, and absence of invasive features or metastatic potential.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Neoplasm, Uncertain Whether Benign or Malignant
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neoplasm which, on morphologic grounds, can not be classified with certainty as benign or malignant.

Concepts.longName: Neoplasm, Uncertain Whether Benign or Malignant
Concepts.definition: A neoplasm which, on morphologic grounds, can not be classified with certainty as benign or malignant.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition with current NCIt. 4.10.19 mc

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor at the original site of growth.

Concepts.definition: A malignant tumor at the original site of growth.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor that has spread from its original (primary) site of growth to another site close to or distant from the primary site.

Concepts.definition: A malignant tumor that has spread from its original (primary) site of growth to another site close to or distant from the primary site.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm, Uncertain Whether Primary or Metastatic
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant neoplasm in which the examined tissue can not be determined with certainty if it represents the primary site of tumor growth or tumor spread from another anatomic site.

Concepts.longName: Malignant Neoplasm, Uncertain Whether Primary or Metastatic
Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm in which the examined tissue can not be determined with certainty if it represents the primary site of tumor growth or tumor spread from another anatomic site.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._The code for the behavior of the tumor being reported using ICD-O-3._A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
The code for the behavior of the tumor being reported using ICD-O-3.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
